pycaret.classification.set_config(variable, value)¶

This function is used to reset global environment variables. Following variables can be accessed:

  • X: Transformed dataset (X)

  • y: Transformed dataset (y)

  • X_train: Transformed train dataset (X)

  • X_test: Transformed test/holdout dataset (X)

  • y_train: Transformed train dataset (y)

  • y_test: Transformed test/holdout dataset (y)

  • seed: random state set through session_id

  • prep_pipe: Transformation pipeline configured through setup

  • folds_shuffle_param: shuffle parameter used in Kfolds

  • n_jobs_param: n_jobs parameter used in model training

  • html_param: html_param configured through setup

  • create_model_container: results grid storage container

  • master_model_container: model storage container

  • display_container: results display container

  • exp_name_log: Name of experiment set through setup

  • logging_param: log_experiment param set through setup

  • log_plots_param: log_plots param set through setup

  • USI: Unique session ID parameter set through setup

  • fix_imbalance_param: fix_imbalance param set through setup

  • fix_imbalance_method_param: fix_imbalance_method param set through setup

    set_config(‘seed’, 123)

    This will set the global seed to ‘123’.

pycaret.classification.setup(data, target, train_size=0.7, sampling=True, sample_estimator=None, categorical_features=None, categorical_imputation='constant', ordinal_features=None, high_cardinality_features=None, high_cardinality_method='frequency', numeric_features=None, numeric_imputation='mean', date_features=None, ignore_features=None, normalize=False, normalize_method='zscore', transformation=False, transformation_method='yeo-johnson', handle_unknown_categorical=True, unknown_categorical_method='least_frequent', pca=False, pca_method='linear', pca_components=None, ignore_low_variance=False, combine_rare_levels=False, rare_level_threshold=0.1, bin_numeric_features=None, remove_outliers=False, outliers_threshold=0.05, remove_multicollinearity=False, multicollinearity_threshold=0.9, remove_perfect_collinearity=False, create_clusters=False, cluster_iter=20, polynomial_features=False, polynomial_degree=2, trigonometry_features=False, polynomial_threshold=0.1, group_features=None, group_names=None, feature_selection=False, feature_selection_threshold=0.8, feature_interaction=False, feature_ratio=False, interaction_threshold=0.01, fix_imbalance=False, fix_imbalance_method=None, data_split_shuffle=True, folds_shuffle=False, n_jobs=- 1, html=True, session_id=None, log_experiment=False, experiment_name=None, log_plots=False, log_profile=False, log_data=False, silent=False, verbose=True, profile=False)¶

This function initializes the environment in pycaret and creates the transformation pipeline to prepare the data for modeling and deployment. setup() must called before executing any other function in pycaret. It takes two mandatory parameters: dataframe {array-like, sparse matrix} and name of the target column.

All other parameters are optional.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data juice = get_data(‘juice’)

experiment_name = setup(data = juice, target = ‘Purchase’)

‘juice’ is a pandas DataFrame and ‘Purchase’ is the name of target column.

Parameters

  • data ({array-like, sparse matrix}, shape (n_samples, n_features) where n_samples) –

  • the number of samples and n_features is the number of features. (is) –

  • target (string) –

  • of the target column to be passed in as a string. The target variable could (Name) –

  • binary or multiclass. In case of a multiclass target (be) –

  • estimators are wrapped (all) –

  • a OneVsRest classifier. (with) –

  • train_size (float, default = 0.7) –

  • of the training set. By default (Size) –

  • of the data will be used for training (70%) –

  • validation. The remaining data will be used for a test / hold-out set. (and) –

  • sampling (bool, default = True) –

  • the sample size exceeds 25 (When) –

  • samples (000) –

  • will build a base estimator (pycaret) –

  • various sample sizes from the original dataset. This will return a performance (at) –

  • of AUC (plot) –

  • Accuracy –

  • Recall –

  • Precision –

  • and F1 values at various sample (Kappa) –

  • levels –

  • will assist in deciding the preferred sample size for modeling. (that) –

  • desired sample size must then be entered for training and validation in the (The) –

  • environment. When sample_size entered is less than 1 (pycaret) –

  • remaining dataset (the) –

  • - sample) is used for fitting the model only when finalize_model() is called. ((1) –

  • sample_estimator (object, default = None) –

  • None (If) –

  • Regression is used by default. (Logistic) –

  • categorical_features (string, default = None) –

  • the inferred data types are not correct (If) –

  • can be used to (numeric_features) –

  • the inferred type. If when running setup the type of 'column1' is (overwrite) –

  • as numeric instead of categorical (inferred) –

  • this parameter can be used (then) –

  • overwrite the type by passing categorical_features = ['column1'] (to) –

  • categorical_imputation (string, default = 'constant') –

  • missing values are found in categorical features (If) –

  • will be imputed with (they) –

  • constant 'not_available' value. The other available option is 'mode' which (a) –

  • the missing value using most frequent value in the training dataset. (imputes) –

  • ordinal_features (dictionary, default = None) –

  • the data contains ordinal features (When) –

  • must be encoded differently using (they) –

  • ordinal_features param. If the data has a categorical variable with values (the) –

  • 'low' (of) –

  • 'medium' –

  • and it is known that low < medium < high ('high') –

  • it can (then) –

  • passed as ordinal_features = { 'column_name' (be) –

  • list sequence must be in increasing order from lowest to highest. (The) –

  • high_cardinality_features (string, default = None) –

  • the data containts features with high cardinality (When) –

  • can be compressed (they) –

  • fewer levels by passing them as a list of column names with high cardinality. (into) –

  • are compressed using method defined in high_cardinality_method param. (Features) –

  • high_cardinality_method (string, default = 'frequency') –

  • method set to 'frequency' it will replace the original value of feature (When) –

  • the frequency distribution and convert the feature into numeric. Other (with) –

  • method is 'clustering' which performs the clustering on statistical (available) –

  • of data and replaces the original value of feature with cluster label. (attribute) –

  • number of clusters is determined using a combination of Calinski-Harabasz and (The) –

  • criterion. (Silhouette) –

  • numeric_features (string, default = None) –

  • the inferred data types are not correct –

  • can be used to –

  • the inferred type. If when running setup the type of 'column1' is –

  • as a categorical instead of numeric (inferred) –

  • this parameter can be used –

  • overwrite by passing numeric_features = ['column1'] (to) –

  • numeric_imputation (string, default = 'mean') –

  • missing values are found in numeric features (If) –

  • will be imputed with the (they) –

  • value of the feature. The other available option is 'median' which imputes (mean) –

  • value using the median value in the training dataset. (the) –

  • date_features (string, default = None) –

  • the data has a DateTime column that is not automatically detected when running (If) –

  • setup –

  • parameter can be used by passing date_features = 'date_column_name'. (this) –

  • can work with multiple date columns. Date columns are not used in modeling. (It) –

  • Instead –

  • extraction is performed and date columns are dropped from the (feature) –

  • If the date column includes a time stamp (dataset.) –

  • related to time will (features) –

  • be extracted. (also) –

  • ignore_features (string, default = None) –

  • any feature should be ignored for modeling (If) –

  • can be passed to the param (it) –

  • The ID and DateTime columns when inferred (ignore_features.) –

  • automatically (are) –

  • to ignore for modeling. (set) –

  • normalize (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True (When) –

  • feature space is transformed using the normalized_method (the) –

  • Generally (param.) –

  • algorithms perform better with normalized data however (linear) –

:param : :param the results may vary and it is advised to run multiple experiments to evaluate: :param the benefit of normalization.: :param normalize_method: :type normalize_method: string, default = 'zscore' :param Defines the method to be used for normalization. By default: :param normalize method: :param is set to ‘zscore’. The standard zscore is calculated as z = (x - u) / s. The: :param other available options are: :param ‘minmax’: the range of 0 - 1. :type ‘minmax’: scales and translates each feature individually such that it is in :param ‘maxabs’: absolute value of each feature will be 1.0. It does not shift/center

the data, and thus does not destroy any sparsity.

Parameters

  • 'robust' (scales and translates each feature according to the Interquartile range.) – When the dataset contains outliers, robust scaler often gives better results.

  • transformation (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True (When) –

  • power transformation is applied to make the data more normal / (a) –

  • This is useful for modeling issues related to heteroscedasticity or (Gaussian-like.) –

  • situations where normality is desired. The optimal parameter for stabilizing (other) –

  • and minimizing skewness is estimated through maximum likelihood. (variance) –

  • transformation_method (string, default = 'yeo-johnson') –

  • the method for transformation. By default (Defines) –

  • transformation method is set (the) –

  • 'yeo-johnson'. The other available option is 'quantile' transformation. Both (to) –

  • transformation transforms the feature set to follow a Gaussian-like or normal (the) –

  • Note that the quantile transformer is non-linear and may distort linear (distribution.) –

  • between variables measured at the same scale. (correlations) –

  • handle_unknown_categorical (bool, default = True) –

  • set to True –

  • categorical levels in new / unseen data are replaced by (unknown) –

  • most or least frequent level as learned in the training data. The method is (the) –

  • under the unknown_categorical_method param. (defined) –

  • unknown_categorical_method (string, default = 'least_frequent') –

  • used to replace unknown categorical levels in unseen data. Method can be (Method) –

  • to 'least_frequent' or 'most_frequent'. (set) –

  • pca (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • reduction is applied to project the data into (dimensionality) –

  • lower dimensional space using the method defined in pca_method param. In (a) –

  • learning pca is generally performed when dealing with high feature (supervised) –

  • and memory is a constraint. Note that not all datasets can be decomposed (space) –

  • using a linear PCA technique and that applying PCA may result in loss (efficiently) –

  • information. As such (of) –

  • is advised to run multiple experiments with different (it) –

  • to evaluate the impact. (pca_methods) –

  • pca_method (string, default = 'linear') –

  • 'linear' method performs Linear dimensionality reduction using Singular Value (The) –

  • The other available options are (Decomposition.) –

  • kernel (dimensionality reduction through the use of RVF kernel.) –

  • incremental (replacement for 'linear' pca when the dataset to be decomposed is) – too large to fit in memory

  • pca_components (int/float, default = 0.99) –

  • of components to keep. if pca_components is a float (Number) –

  • is treated as a (it) –

  • percentage for information retention. When pca_components is an integer (target) –

  • is treated as the number of features to be kept. pca_components must be strictly (it) –

  • than the original number of features in the dataset. (less) –

  • ignore_low_variance (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • categorical features with statistically insignificant variances (all) –

  • removed from the dataset. The variance is calculated using the ratio of unique (are) –

  • to the number of samples (values) –

  • the ratio of the most common value to the (and) –

  • of the second most common value. (frequency) –

  • combine_rare_levels (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • levels in categorical features below the threshold defined (all) –

  • rare_level_threshold param are combined together as a single level. There must be (in) –

  • two levels under the threshold for this to take effect. rare_level_threshold (atleast) –

  • the percentile distribution of level frequency. Generally (represents) –

  • technique (this) –

  • applied to limit a sparse matrix caused by high numbers of levels in categorical (is) –

  • features. –

  • rare_level_threshold (float, default = 0.1) –

  • distribution below which rare categories are combined. Only comes into (Percentile) –

  • when combine_rare_levels is set to True. (effect) –

  • bin_numeric_features (list, default = None) –

  • a list of numeric features is passed they are transformed into categorical (When) –

  • using KMeans (features) –

  • values in each bin have the same nearest center of a (where) –

  • k-means cluster. The number of clusters are determined based on the 'sturges' (1D) –

  • It is only optimal for gaussian data and underestimates the number of bins (method.) –

  • large non-gaussian datasets. (for) –

  • remove_outliers (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • from the training data are removed using PCA linear (outliers) –

  • reduction using the Singular Value Decomposition technique. (dimensionality) –

  • outliers_threshold (float, default = 0.05) –

  • percentage / proportion of outliers in the dataset can be defined using (The) –

  • outliers_threshold param. By default (the) –

  • is used which means 0.025 of the (0.05) –

  • on each side of the distribution's tail are dropped from training data. (values) –

  • remove_multicollinearity (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • variables with inter-correlations higher than the threshold (the) –

  • under the multicollinearity_threshold param are dropped. When two features (defined) –

  • highly correlated with each other (are) –

  • feature that is less correlated with (the) –

  • target variable is dropped. (the) –

  • multicollinearity_threshold (float, default = 0.9) –

  • used for dropping the correlated features. Only comes into effect when (Threshold) –

  • is set to True. (remove_multicollinearity) –

  • remove_perfect_collinearity (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • collinearity (features with correlation = 1) is removed (perfect) –

  • the dataset (from) –

  • two features are 100% correlated (When) –

  • of it is randomly (one) –

  • from the dataset. (dropped) –

  • create_clusters (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • additional feature is created where each instance is assigned (an) –

  • a cluster. The number of clusters is determined using a combination of (to) –

  • and Silhouette criterion. (Calinski-Harabasz) –

  • cluster_iter (int, default = 20) –

  • of iterations used to create a cluster. Each iteration represents cluster (Number) –

  • Only comes into effect when create_clusters param is set to True. (size.) –

  • polynomial_features (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • features are created based on all polynomial combinations (new) –

  • exist within the numeric features in a dataset to the degree defined in (that) –

  • param. (polynomial_degree) –

  • polynomial_degree (int, default = 2) –

  • of polynomial features. For example (Degree) –

  • an input sample is two dimensional (if) –

  • of the form [a (and) –

  • b] –

  • polynomial features with degree = 2 are (the) –

  • [1 –

  • a –

  • b –

  • a^2 –

  • ab –

  • b^2] –

  • trigonometry_features (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • features are created based on all trigonometric combinations (new) –

  • exist within the numeric features in a dataset to the degree defined in the (that) –

  • param. –

  • polynomial_threshold (float, default = 0.1) –

  • is used to compress a sparse matrix of polynomial and trigonometric features. (This) –

  • and trigonometric features whose feature importance based on the (Polynomial) –

  • of Random Forest (combination) –

  • and Linear correlation falls within the (AdaBoost) –

  • of the defined threshold are kept in the dataset. Remaining features (percentile) –

  • dropped before further processing. (are) –

  • group_features (the) –

  • a dataset contains features that have related characteristics (When) –

  • group_features –

  • can be used for statistical feature extraction. For example (param) –

  • a dataset has (if) –

  • features that are related with each other (i.e 'Col1' (numeric) –

  • 'Col2' –

  • 'Col3') –

  • list (a) –

  • the column names can be passed under group_features to extract statistical (containing) –

  • such as the mean (information) –

  • median –

  • and standard deviation. (mode) –

  • group_names (list, default = None) –

  • group_features is passed (When) –

  • name of the group can be passed into the group_names (a) –

  • as a list containing strings. The length of a group_names list must equal to the (param) –

  • of group_features. When the length doesn't match or the name is not passed (length) –

  • new –

  • are sequentially named such as group_1 (features) –

  • etc. (group_2) –

  • feature_selection (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • subset of features are selected using a combination of various (a) –

  • importance techniques including Random Forest (permutation) –

  • and Linear (Adaboost) –

  • with target variable. The size of the subset is dependent on the (correlation) –

  • Generally (feature_selection_param.) –

  • is used to constrain the feature space (this) –

  • order to improve efficiency in modeling. When polynomial_features and (in) –

  • are used (feature_interaction) –

  • is highly recommended to define the (it) –

  • param with a lower value. (feature_selection_threshold) –

  • feature_selection_threshold (float, default = 0.8) –

  • used for feature selection (including newly created polynomial features) (Threshold) –

  • higher value will result in a higher feature space. It is recommended to do multiple (A) –

  • with different values of feature_selection_threshold specially in cases where (trials) –

  • and feature_interaction are used. Setting a very low value may be (polynomial_features) –

  • but could result in under-fitting. (efficient) –

  • feature_interaction (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • will create new features by interacting (a * b) for all numeric (it) –

  • in the dataset including polynomial and trigonometric features (if created) (variables) –

  • feature is not scalable and may not work as expected on datasets with large (This) –

  • space. (feature) –

  • feature_ratio (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • will create new features by calculating the ratios (a / b) of all (it) –

  • variables in the dataset. This feature is not scalable and may not work as (numeric) –

  • on datasets with large feature space. (expected) –

  • interaction_threshold (bool, default = 0.01) –

  • to polynomial_threshold (Similar) –

  • is used to compress a sparse matrix of newly (It) –

  • features through interaction. Features whose importance based on the (created) –

  • of Random Forest (combination) –

  • and Linear correlation falls within the –

  • of the defined threshold are kept in the dataset. Remaining features (percentile) –

  • dropped before further processing. –

  • fix_imbalance (bool, default = False) –

  • dataset has unequal distribution of target class it can be fixed using (When) –

  • parameter. When set to True (fix_imbalance) –

  • (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling (SMOTE) –

  • is applied by default to create synthetic datapoints for minority class. (Technique)) –

  • fix_imbalance_method (obj, default = None) –

  • fix_imbalance is set to True and fix_imbalance_method is None (When) –

  • is applied ('smote') –

  • default to oversample minority class during cross validation. This parameter (by) –

  • any module from 'imblearn' that supports 'fit_resample' method. (accepts) –

  • data_split_shuffle (bool, default = True) –

  • set to False (If) –

  • shuffling of rows when splitting data. (prevents) –

  • folds_shuffle (bool, default = False) –

  • set to False –

  • shuffling of rows when using cross validation. (prevents) –

  • n_jobs (int, default = -1) –

  • number of jobs to run in parallel (for functions that supports parallel (The) –

  • -1 means using all processors. To run all functions on single processor (processing)) –

  • n_jobs to None. (set) –

  • html (bool, default = True) –

  • set to False –

  • runtime display of monitor. This must be set to False (prevents) –

  • using environment that doesnt support HTML. (when) –

  • session_id (int, default = None) –

  • None (If) –

  • random seed is generated and returned in the Information grid. The (a) –

  • number is then distributed as a seed in all functions used during the (unique) –

  • This can be used for later reproducibility of the entire experiment. (experiment.) –

  • log_experiment (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • metrics and parameters are logged on MLFlow server. (all) –

  • experiment_name (str, default = None) –

  • of experiment for logging. When set to None (Name) –

  • is by default used as ('clf') –

  • for the experiment name. (alias) –

  • log_plots (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • plots are logged in MLflow as a png file. By default (specific) –

:param : :param it is set to False.: :param log_profile: :type log_profile: bool, default = False :param When set to True: :param data profile is also logged on MLflow as a html file. By default: :param : :param it is set to False.: :param log_data: :type log_data: bool, default = False :param When set to True: :param train and test dataset are logged as csv.: :param silent: :type silent: bool, default = False :param When set to True: :param confirmation of data types is not required. All preprocessing will: :param be performed assuming automatically inferred data types. Not recommended for direct use: :param except for established pipelines.: :param verbose: :type verbose: Boolean, default = True :param Information grid is not printed when verbose is set to False.: :param profile: :type profile: bool, default = False :param If set to true: :param a data profile for Exploratory Data Analysis will be displayed: :param in an interactive HTML report.: :param Returns: :param ——–: :param info grid: :type info grid: Information grid is printed. :param ———–: :param environment: :type environment: This function returns various outputs that are stored in variables :param ———– as tuples. They are used by other functions in pycaret.:

pycaret.classification.stack_models(estimator_list, meta_model=None, fold=10, round=4, method='auto', restack=True, choose_better=False, optimize='Accuracy', verbose=True)¶

This function trains a meta model and scores it using Stratified Cross Validation. The predictions from the base level models as passed in the estimator_list param are used as input features for the meta model. The restacking parameter controls the ability to expose raw features to the meta model when set to True (default = False).

The output prints the score grid that shows Accuracy, AUC, Recall, Precision, F1, Kappa and MCC by fold (default = 10 Folds).

This function returns a trained model object.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data juice = get_data(‘juice’) experiment_name = setup(data = juice, target = ‘Purchase’) dt = create_model(‘dt’) rf = create_model(‘rf’) ada = create_model(‘ada’) ridge = create_model(‘ridge’) knn = create_model(‘knn’)

stacked_models = stack_models(estimator_list=[dt,rf,ada,ridge,knn])

This will create a meta model that will use the predictions of all the models provided in estimator_list param. By default, the meta model is Logistic Regression but can be changed with meta_model param.

Parameters

  • estimator_list (list of objects) –

  • meta_model (object, default = None) –

  • set to None (if) –

  • Regression is used as a meta model. (Logistic) –

  • fold (integer, default = 10) –

  • of folds to be used in Kfold CV. Must be at least 2. (Number) –

  • round (integer, default = 4) –

  • of decimal places the metrics in the score grid will be rounded to. (Number) –

  • method (string, default = 'auto') –

  • if ‘auto’ (-) –

  • will try to invoke (it) –

  • each estimator (for) –

  • 'predict_proba' –

:param : :param ‘decision_function’ or ‘predict’ in that order.: :param - otherwise: :param one of ‘predict_proba’: :param ‘decision_function’ or ‘predict’.: :param If the method is not implemented by the estimator: :param it will raise an error.: :param restack: :type restack: Boolean, default = True :param When restack is set to True: :param raw data will be exposed to meta model when: :param making predictions: :param otherwise when False: :param only the predicted label or: :param probabilities is passed to meta model when making final predictions.: :param choose_better: :type choose_better: Boolean, default = False :param When set to set to True: :param base estimator is returned when the metric doesn’t: :param improve by ensemble_model. This gurantees the returned object would perform: :param atleast equivalent to base estimator created using create_model or model: :param returned by compare_models.: :param optimize: :type optimize: string, default = 'Accuracy' :param Only used when choose_better is set to True. optimize parameter is used: :param to compare emsembled model with base estimator. Values accepted in: :param optimize parameter are ‘Accuracy’: :param ‘AUC’: :param ‘Recall’: :param ‘Precision’: :param ‘F1’: :param : :param ‘Kappa’: :param ‘MCC’.: :param verbose: :type verbose: Boolean, default = True :param Score grid is not printed when verbose is set to False.: :param Returns: :param ——–: :param score grid: :type score grid: A table containing the scores of the model across the kfolds. :param ———– Scoring metrics used are Accuracy: Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across

the folds are also returned.

Parameters

  • AUC – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • Recall – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • Precision – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • F1 – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

:paramKappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across

the folds are also returned.

Parameters

  • model (trained model object.) –

  • ----------- –

  • Warnings –

  • --------- –

  • If target variable is multiclass (more than 2 classes) (-) – as zero (0.0).

  • will be returned (AUC) – as zero (0.0).

pycaret.classification.tune_model(estimator=None, fold=10, round=4, n_iter=10, custom_grid=None, optimize='Accuracy', choose_better=False, verbose=True)¶

This function tunes the hyperparameters of a model and scores it using Stratified Cross Validation. The output prints a score grid that shows Accuracy, AUC, Recall Precision, F1, Kappa and MCC by fold (by default = 10 Folds).

This function returns a trained model object.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data juice = get_data(‘juice’) experiment_name = setup(data = juice, target = ‘Purchase’) xgboost = create_model(‘xgboost’)

tuned_xgboost = tune_model(xgboost)

This will tune the hyperparameters of Extreme Gradient Boosting Classifier.

Parameters

  • estimator (object, default = None) –

  • fold (integer, default = 10) –

  • of folds to be used in Kfold CV. Must be at least 2. (Number) –

  • round (integer, default = 4) –

  • of decimal places the metrics in the score grid will be rounded to. (Number) –

  • n_iter (integer, default = 10) –

  • of iterations within the Random Grid Search. For every iteration (Number) –

:param : :param the model randomly selects one value from the pre-defined grid of hyperparameters.: :param custom_grid: :type custom_grid: dictionary, default = None :param To use custom hyperparameters for tuning pass a dictionary with parameter name: :param and values to be iterated. When set to None it uses pre-defined tuning grid.: :param optimize: :type optimize: string, default = 'accuracy' :param Measure used to select the best model through hyperparameter tuning.: :param The default scoring measure is ‘Accuracy’. Other measures include ‘AUC’: :param : :param ‘Recall’: :param ‘Precision’: :param ‘F1’.: :param choose_better: :type choose_better: Boolean, default = False :param When set to set to True: :param base estimator is returned when the performance doesn’t: :param improve by tune_model. This gurantees the returned object would perform atleast: :param equivalent to base estimator created using create_model or model returned by: :param compare_models.: :param verbose: :type verbose: Boolean, default = True :param Score grid is not printed when verbose is set to False.: :param Returns: :param ——–: :param score grid: :type score grid: A table containing the scores of the model across the kfolds. :param ———– Scoring metrics used are Accuracy: Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across

the folds are also returned.

Parameters

  • AUC – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • Recall – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • Precision – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

  • F1 – Kappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across the folds are also returned.

:paramKappa and MCC. Mean and standard deviation of the scores across

the folds are also returned.

Parameters

  • model (trained and tuned model object.) –

  • ----------- –

  • Warnings –

  • --------- –

  • If target variable is multiclass (more than 2 classes) (-) – not acceptable.

  • param 'AUC' is (optimize) – not acceptable.

  • If target variable is multiclass (more than 2 classes) – zero (0.0)

  • will be returned as (AUC) – zero (0.0)

Arules¶

pycaret.arules.create_model(metric='confidence', threshold=0.5, min_support=0.05, round=4)¶

This function creates an association rules model using data and identifiers passed at setup stage. This function internally transforms the data for association rule mining.

setup() function must be called before using create_model()

from pycaret.datasets import get_data france get_data(‘france’) experiment_name = setup(data = data, transaction_id = ‘InvoiceNo’,

item_id = ‘ProductName’)

This will return dataframe containing rules sorted by metric param.

Parameters

  • metric (string, default = 'confidence') –

  • to evaluate if a rule is of interest. Default is set to confidence. (Metric) –

  • available metrics include 'support' (Other) –

  • 'lift' –

  • 'leverage' –

  • 'conviction'. –

  • metrics are computed as follows (These) –

  • support(A->C) = support(A+C) [aka 'support'] (-) –

  • range ([0, inf]) –

  • confidence(A->C) = support(A+C) / support(A) (-) –

  • range –

  • lift(A->C) = confidence(A->C) / support(C) (-) –

  • range –

  • leverage(A->C) = support(A->C) - support(A)*support(C) (-) – range: [-1, 1]

:param : range: [-1, 1] :param - conviction = [1 - support(C)] / [1 - confidence(A->C)]: range: [0, inf] :param : range: [0, inf] :param threshold: :type threshold: float, default = 0.5 :param Minimal threshold for the evaluation metric: :param via the metric parameter: :param : :param to decide whether a candidate rule is of interest.: :param min_support: :type min_support: float, default = 0.05 :param A float between 0 and 1 for minumum support of the itemsets returned.: :param The support is computed as the fraction transactions_where_item(s)_occur /: :param total_transactions.: :param round: :type round: integer, default = 4 :param Number of decimal places metrics in score grid will be rounded to.:

DataFrame: Dataframe containing rules of interest with all metrics ——— including antecedents, consequents, antecedent support,

consequent support, support, confidence, lift, leverage, conviction.

  • Setting low values for min_support may increase training time.

pycaret.arules.get_rules(data, transaction_id, item_id, ignore_items=None, metric='confidence', threshold=0.5, min_support=0.05)¶

Magic function to get Association Rules in Power Query / Power BI.

rule1 = create_model(metric=’confidence’, threshold=0.7, min_support=0.05) plot_model(rule1, plot=’2d’) plot_model(rule1, plot=’3d’)

Parameters

  • model (DataFrame, default = none) –

  • returned by trained model using create_model() (DataFrame) –

  • plot (string, default = '2d') –

  • abbreviation of type of plot. The current list of plots supported are (Enter) –

  • Abbreviated String (Name) –

  • ------------------ (---------) –

  • Support –

  • and Lift (2d) '2d' (Confidence) –

  • Support –

  • and Lift (3d) '3d' (Confidence) –

pycaret.arules.setup(data, transaction_id, item_id, ignore_items=None, session_id=None)¶

This function initializes the environment in pycaret. setup() must called before executing any other function in pycaret. It takes three mandatory parameters: (i) dataframe {array-like, sparse matrix}, (ii) transaction_id param identifying basket and (iii) item_id param used to create rules. These three params are normally found in any transactional dataset. pycaret will internally convert the dataframe into a sparse matrix which is required for association rules mining.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data france get_data(‘france’)

experiment_name = setup(data = data, transaction_id = ‘InvoiceNo’,

item_id = ‘ProductName’)

Parameters

  • data ({array-like, sparse matrix}, shape (n_samples, n_features) where n_samples) –

  • the number of samples and n_features is the number of features. (is) –

  • transaction_id (string) –

  • of column representing transaction id. This will be used to pivot the matrix. (Name) –

  • item_id (string) –

  • of column used for creation of rules. Normally (Name) –

  • will be the variable of (this) –

  • interest. –

  • ignore_items (list, default = None) –

  • of strings to be ignored when considering rule mining. (list) –

  • session_id (int, default = None) –

  • None (If) –

  • random seed is generated and returned in the Information grid. The (a) –

  • number is then distributed as a seed in all functions used during the (unique) –

  • This can be used for later reproducibility of the entire experiment. (experiment.) –

  • Returns –

  • -------- –

  • grid (info) –

  • ----------- –

  • environment (This function returns various outputs that are stored in variable) –

  • as tuple. They are used by other functions in pycaret. (-----------) –

Anomaly¶

pycaret.anomaly.assign_model(model, transformation=False, score=True, verbose=True)¶

This function flags each of the data point in the dataset passed during setup stage as either outlier or inlier (1 = outlier, 0 = inlier) using trained model object passed as model param. create_model() function must be called before using assign_model().

This function returns dataframe with Outlier flag (1 = outlier, 0 = inlier) and decision score, when score is set to True.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’) experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly, normalize = True) knn = create_model(‘knn’)

knn_df = assign_model(knn)

This will return a dataframe with inferred outliers using trained model.

Parameters

  • model (trained model object, default = None) –

  • transformation (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True (When) –

  • outliers are returned on transformed dataset instead (assigned) –

  • original dataset passed during setup() (of) –

  • score (Boolean, default = True) –

  • outlier scores of the training data. The higher (The) –

  • more abnormal. (the) –

  • tend to have higher scores. This value is available once the model (Outliers) –

  • fitted. If set to False (is) –

  • will only return the flag (1 = outlier (it) –

  • = inlier) (0) –

  • verbose (Boolean, default = True) –

  • update is not printed when verbose is set to False. (Status) –

  • Returns –

  • -------- –

  • dataframe (Returns a dataframe with inferred outliers using a trained model.) –

  • --------- –

pycaret.anomaly.create_model(model=None, fraction=0.05, verbose=True, system=True, **kwargs)¶

This function creates a model on the dataset passed as a data param during the setup stage. setup() function must be called before using create_model().

This function returns a trained model object.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’) experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly, normalize = True)

knn = create_model(‘knn’)

This will return trained k-Nearest Neighbors model.

Parameters

  • model (trained model object) –

  • ID of the models available in model library or pass an untrained model (Enter) –

  • consistent with fit / predict API to train and evaluate model. List of (object) –

  • available in model library (models) –

  • Model (ID) –

  • --------- (-------) –

  • Angle-base Outlier Detection ('abod') –

  • Clustering-Based Local Outlier ('cluster') –

  • Connectivity-Based Outlier Factor ('cof') –

  • Histogram-based Outlier Detection ('histogram') –

  • k-Nearest Neighbors Detector ('knn') –

  • Local Outlier Factor ('lof') –

  • One-class SVM detector ('svm') –

  • Principal Component Analysis ('pca') –

  • Minimum Covariance Determinant ('mcd') –

  • Subspace Outlier Detection ('sod') –

  • Stochastic Outlier Selection ('sos') –

  • fraction (float, default = 0.05) –

  • percentage / proportion of outliers in the dataset. (The) –

  • verbose (Boolean, default = True) –

  • update is not printed when verbose is set to False. (Status) –

  • system (Boolean, default = True) –

  • remain True all times. Only to be changed by internal functions. (Must) –

  • **kwargs –

  • keyword arguments to pass to the estimator. (Additional) –

  • Returns –

  • -------- –

  • model –

  • ------ –

pycaret.anomaly.deploy_model(model, model_name, authentication, platform='aws')¶

(In Preview)

This function deploys the transformation pipeline and trained model object for production use. The platform of deployment can be defined under the platform param along with the applicable authentication tokens which are passed as a dictionary to the authentication param.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’) experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly, normalize=True) knn = create_model(‘knn’)

deploy_model(model = knn, model_name = ‘deploy_knn’, platform = ‘aws’,

authentication = {‘bucket’ : ‘pycaret-test’})

This will deploy the model on an AWS S3 account under bucket ‘pycaret-test’

Before deploying a model to an AWS S3 (‘aws’), environment variables must be configured using the command line interface. To configure AWS env. variables, type aws configure in your python command line. The following information is required which can be generated using the Identity and Access Management (IAM) portal of your amazon console account:

  • AWS Access Key ID

  • AWS Secret Key Access

  • Default Region Name (can be seen under Global settings on your AWS console)

  • Default output format (must be left blank)

Parameters

  • model (object) –

  • trained model object should be passed as an estimator. (A) –

  • model_name (string) –

  • of model to be passed as a string. (Name) –

  • authentication (dict) –

  • of applicable authentication tokens. (dictionary) – When platform = ‘aws’: {‘bucket’ : ‘Name of Bucket on S3’}

  • platform (string, default = 'aws') –

  • of platform for deployment. Current available options are (Name) –

  • Returns –

  • -------- –

  • Message (Success) –

pycaret.anomaly.get_config(variable)¶

This function is used to access global environment variables. Following variables can be accessed:

  • X: Transformed dataset

  • data_: Original dataset

  • seed: random state set through session_id

  • prep_pipe: Transformation pipeline configured through setup

  • prep_param: prep_param configured through setup

  • n_jobs_param: n_jobs parameter used in model training

  • html_param: html_param configured through setup

  • exp_name_log: Name of experiment set through setup

  • logging_param: log_experiment param set through setup

  • log_plots_param: log_plots param set through setup

  • USI: Unique session ID parameter set through setup

    X = get_config(‘X’)

    This will return transformed dataset.

pycaret.anomaly.predict_model(model, data, platform=None, authentication=None)¶

This function is used to predict new data using a trained model. It requires a trained model object created using one of the function in pycaret that returns a trained model object. New data must be passed to data param as pandas Dataframe.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’) experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly) knn = create_model(‘knn’)

knn_predictions = predict_model(model = knn, data = anomaly)

  • the number of samples and n_features is the number of features. All features (is) –

  • during training must be present in the new dataset. (used) –

  • platform (string, default = None) –

  • of platform (Name) –

  • loading model from cloud. Current available options are (if) –

  • 'aws'. –

  • authentication (dict) –

pycaret.anomaly.save_model(model, model_name, verbose=True)¶

This function saves the transformation pipeline and trained model object into the current active directory as a pickle file for later use.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’) experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly, normalize = True) knn = create_model(‘knn’)

save_model(knn, ‘knn_model_23122019’)

This will save the transformation pipeline and model as a binary pickle file in the current directory.

Parameters

  • model (object, default = none) –

  • trained model object should be passed. (A) –

  • model_name (string, default = none) –

  • of pickle file to be passed as a string. (Name) –

  • verbose (bool, default = True) –

  • set to False (When) –

  • message is not printed. (success) –

  • Returns –

  • -------- –

  • Message (Success) –

pycaret.anomaly.set_config(variable, value)¶

This function is used to reset global environment variables. Following variables can be accessed:

  • X: Transformed dataset

  • data_: Original dataset

  • seed: random state set through session_id

  • prep_pipe: Transformation pipeline configured through setup

  • prep_param: prep_param configured through setup

  • n_jobs_param: n_jobs parameter used in model training

  • html_param: html_param configured through setup

  • exp_name_log: Name of experiment set through setup

  • logging_param: log_experiment param set through setup

  • log_plots_param: log_plots param set through setup

  • USI: Unique session ID parameter set through setup

    set_config(‘seed’, 123)

    This will set the global seed to ‘123’.

pycaret.anomaly.setup(data, categorical_features=None, categorical_imputation='constant', ordinal_features=None, high_cardinality_features=None, numeric_features=None, numeric_imputation='mean', date_features=None, ignore_features=None, normalize=False, normalize_method='zscore', transformation=False, transformation_method='yeo-johnson', handle_unknown_categorical=True, unknown_categorical_method='least_frequent', pca=False, pca_method='linear', pca_components=None, ignore_low_variance=False, combine_rare_levels=False, rare_level_threshold=0.1, bin_numeric_features=None, remove_multicollinearity=False, multicollinearity_threshold=0.9, group_features=None, group_names=None, supervised=False, supervised_target=None, n_jobs=- 1, html=True, session_id=None, log_experiment=False, experiment_name=None, log_plots=False, log_profile=False, log_data=False, silent=False, verbose=True, profile=False)¶

This function initializes the environment in pycaret. setup() must called before executing any other function in pycaret. It takes one mandatory parameter: dataframe {array-like, sparse matrix}.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data anomaly = get_data(‘anomaly’)

experiment_name = setup(data = anomaly, normalize = True)

‘anomaly’ is a pandas Dataframe.

Parameters

  • data ({array-like, sparse matrix}, shape (n_samples, n_features) where n_samples) –

  • the number of samples and n_features is the number of features in dataframe. (is) –

  • categorical_features (string, default = None) –

  • the inferred data types are not correct (If) –

  • can be used to (numeric_features) –

  • the inferred type. If when running setup the type of 'column1' is (overwrite) –

  • as numeric instead of categorical (inferred) –

  • this parameter can be used (then) –

  • overwrite the type by passing categorical_features = ['column1'] (to) –

  • categorical_imputation (string, default = 'constant') –

  • missing values are found in categorical features (If) –

  • will be imputed with (they) –

  • constant 'not_available' value. The other available option is 'mode' which (a) –

  • the missing value using most frequent value in the training dataset. (imputes) –

  • ordinal_features (dictionary, default = None) –

  • the data contains ordinal features (When) –

  • must be encoded differently using (they) –

  • ordinal_features param. If the data has a categorical variable with values (the) –

  • 'low' (of) –

  • 'medium' –

  • and it is known that low < medium < high ('high') –

  • it can (then) –

  • passed as ordinal_features = { 'column_name' (be) –

  • list sequence must be in increasing order from lowest to highest. (The) –

  • high_cardinality_features (string, default = None) –

  • the data containts features with high cardinality (When) –

  • can be compressed (they) –

  • fewer levels by passing them as a list of column names with high cardinality. (into) –

  • are compressed using frequency distribution. As such original features (Features) –

  • replaced with the frequency distribution and converted into numeric variable. (are) –

  • numeric_features (string, default = None) –

  • the inferred data types are not correct –

  • can be used to –

  • the inferred type. If when running setup the type of 'column1' is –

  • as a categorical instead of numeric (inferred) –

  • this parameter can be used –

  • overwrite by passing numeric_features = ['column1'] (to) –

  • numeric_imputation (string, default = 'mean') –

  • missing values are found in numeric features (If) –

  • will be imputed with the (they) –

  • value of the feature. The other available option is 'median' which imputes (mean) –

  • value using the median value in the training dataset. (the) –

  • date_features (string, default = None) –

  • the data has a DateTime column that is not automatically detected when running (If) –

  • setup –

  • parameter can be used by passing date_features = 'date_column_name'. (this) –

  • can work with multiple date columns. Date columns are not used in modeling. (It) –

  • Instead –

  • extraction is performed and date columns are dropped from the (feature) –

  • If the date column includes a time stamp (dataset.) –

  • related to time will (features) –

  • be extracted. (also) –

  • ignore_features (string, default = None) –

  • any feature should be ignored for modeling (If) –

  • can be passed to the param (it) –

  • The ID and DateTime columns when inferred (ignore_features.) –

  • automatically (are) –

  • to ignore for modeling. (set) –

  • normalize (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True (When) –

  • feature space is transformed using the normalized_method (the) –

  • Generally (param.) –

  • algorithms perform better with normalized data however (linear) –

:param : :param the results may vary and it is advised to run multiple experiments to evaluate: :param the benefit of normalization.: :param normalize_method: :type normalize_method: string, default = 'zscore' :param Defines the method to be used for normalization. By default: :param normalize method: :param is set to ‘zscore’. The standard zscore is calculated as z = (x - u) / s. The: :param other available options are: :param ‘minmax’: the range of 0 - 1. :type ‘minmax’: scales and translates each feature individually such that it is in :param ‘maxabs’: absolute value of each feature will be 1.0. It does not shift/center

the data, and thus does not destroy any sparsity.

Parameters

  • 'robust' (scales and translates each feature according to the Interquartile range.) – When the dataset contains outliers, robust scaler often gives better results.

  • transformation (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True (When) –

  • power transformation is applied to make the data more normal / (a) –

  • This is useful for modeling issues related to heteroscedasticity or (Gaussian-like.) –

  • situations where normality is desired. The optimal parameter for stabilizing (other) –

  • and minimizing skewness is estimated through maximum likelihood. (variance) –

  • transformation_method (string, default = 'yeo-johnson') –

  • the method for transformation. By default (Defines) –

  • transformation method is set (the) –

  • 'yeo-johnson'. The other available option is 'quantile' transformation. Both (to) –

  • transformation transforms the feature set to follow a Gaussian-like or normal (the) –

  • Note that the quantile transformer is non-linear and may distort linear (distribution.) –

  • between variables measured at the same scale. (correlations) –

  • handle_unknown_categorical (bool, default = True) –

  • set to True –

  • categorical levels in new / unseen data are replaced by (unknown) –

  • most or least frequent level as learned in the training data. The method is (the) –

  • under the unknown_categorical_method param. (defined) –

  • unknown_categorical_method (string, default = 'least_frequent') –

  • used to replace unknown categorical levels in unseen data. Method can be (Method) –

  • to 'least_frequent' or 'most_frequent'. (set) –

  • pca (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • reduction is applied to project the data into (dimensionality) –

  • lower dimensional space using the method defined in pca_method param. In (a) –

  • learning pca is generally performed when dealing with high feature (supervised) –

  • and memory is a constraint. Note that not all datasets can be decomposed (space) –

  • using a linear PCA technique and that applying PCA may result in loss (efficiently) –

  • information. As such (of) –

  • is advised to run multiple experiments with different (it) –

  • to evaluate the impact. (pca_methods) –

  • pca_method (string, default = 'linear') –

  • 'linear' method performs Linear dimensionality reduction using Singular Value (The) –

  • The other available options are (Decomposition.) –

  • kernel (dimensionality reduction through the use of RVF kernel.) –

  • incremental (replacement for 'linear' pca when the dataset to be decomposed is) – too large to fit in memory

  • pca_components (int/float, default = 0.99) –

  • of components to keep. if pca_components is a float (Number) –

  • is treated as a (it) –

  • percentage for information retention. When pca_components is an integer (target) –

  • is treated as the number of features to be kept. pca_components must be strictly (it) –

  • than the original number of features in the dataset. (less) –

  • ignore_low_variance (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • categorical features with statistically insignificant variances (all) –

  • removed from the dataset. The variance is calculated using the ratio of unique (are) –

  • to the number of samples (values) –

  • the ratio of the most common value to the (and) –

  • of the second most common value. (frequency) –

  • combine_rare_levels (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • levels in categorical features below the threshold defined (all) –

  • rare_level_threshold param are combined together as a single level. There must be (in) –

  • two levels under the threshold for this to take effect. rare_level_threshold (atleast) –

  • the percentile distribution of level frequency. Generally (represents) –

  • technique (this) –

  • applied to limit a sparse matrix caused by high numbers of levels in categorical (is) –

  • features. –

  • rare_level_threshold (float, default = 0.1) –

  • distribution below which rare categories are combined. Only comes into (Percentile) –

  • when combine_rare_levels is set to True. (effect) –

  • bin_numeric_features (list, default = None) –

  • a list of numeric features is passed they are transformed into categorical (When) –

  • using KMeans (features) –

  • values in each bin have the same nearest center of a (where) –

  • k-means cluster. The number of clusters are determined based on the 'sturges' (1D) –

  • It is only optimal for gaussian data and underestimates the number of bins (method.) –

  • large non-gaussian datasets. (for) –

  • remove_multicollinearity (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • variables with inter-correlations higher than the threshold (the) –

  • under the multicollinearity_threshold param are dropped. When two features (defined) –

  • highly correlated with each other (are) –

  • feature with higher average correlation (the) –

  • the feature space is dropped. (in) –

  • multicollinearity_threshold (float, default = 0.9) –

  • used for dropping the correlated features. Only comes into effect when (Threshold) –

  • is set to True. (remove_multicollinearity) –

  • group_features (the) –

  • a dataset contains features that have related characteristics (When) –

  • group_features –

  • can be used for statistical feature extraction. For example (param) –

  • a dataset has (if) –

  • features that are related with each other (i.e 'Col1' (numeric) –

  • 'Col2' –

  • 'Col3') –

  • list (a) –

  • the column names can be passed under group_features to extract statistical (containing) –

  • such as the mean (information) –

  • median –

  • and standard deviation. (mode) –

  • group_names (list, default = None) –

  • group_features is passed (When) –

  • name of the group can be passed into the group_names (a) –

  • as a list containing strings. The length of a group_names list must equal to the (param) –

  • of group_features. When the length doesn't match or the name is not passed (length) –

  • new –

  • are sequentially named such as group_1 (features) –

  • etc. (group_2) –

  • supervised (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • column is ignored for transformation. This (supervised_target) –

  • is only for internal use. (param) –

  • supervised_target (string, default = None) –

  • of supervised_target column that will be ignored for transformation. Only (Name) –

  • when tune_model() function is used. This param is only for internal use. (applicable) –

  • n_jobs (int, default = -1) –

  • number of jobs to run in parallel (for functions that supports parallel (The) –

  • -1 means using all processors. To run all functions on single processor (processing)) –

  • n_jobs to None. (set) –

  • html (bool, default = True) –

  • set to False (If) –

  • runtime display of monitor. This must be set to False (prevents) –

  • using environment that doesnt support HTML. (when) –

  • session_id (int, default = None) –

  • None (If) –

  • random seed is generated and returned in the Information grid. The (a) –

  • number is then distributed as a seed in all functions used during the (unique) –

  • This can be used for later reproducibility of the entire experiment. (experiment.) –

  • log_experiment (bool, default = True) –

  • set to True –

  • metrics and parameters are logged on MLFlow server. (all) –

  • experiment_name (str, default = None) –

  • of experiment for logging. When set to None (Name) –

  • is by default used as ('clf') –

  • for the experiment name. (alias) –

  • log_plots (bool, default = False) –

  • set to True –

  • plots are logged in MLflow as a png file. By default (specific) –

:param : :param it is set to False.: :param log_profile: :type log_profile: bool, default = False :param When set to True: :param data profile is also logged on MLflow as a html file. By default: :param : :param it is set to False.: :param silent: :type silent: bool, default = False :param When set to True: :param confirmation of data types is not required. All preprocessing will: :param be performed assuming automatically inferred data types. Not recommended for direct use: :param except for established pipelines.: :param verbose: :type verbose: Boolean, default = True :param Information grid is not printed when verbose is set to False.: :param profile: :type profile: bool, default = False :param If set to true: :param a data profile for Exploratory Data Analysis will be displayed: :param in an interactive HTML report.: :param Returns: :param ——–: :param info grid: :type info grid: Information grid is printed. :param ———–: :param environment: :type environment: This function returns various outputs that are stored in variable :param ———– as tuple. They are used by other functions in pycaret.:

pycaret.anomaly.tune_model(model=None, supervised_target=None, method='drop', estimator=None, optimize=None, custom_grid=None, fold=10, verbose=True)¶

This function tunes the fraction parameter using a predefined grid with the objective of optimizing a supervised learning metric as defined in the optimize param. You can choose the supervised estimator from a large library available in pycaret. By default, supervised estimator is Linear.

This function returns the tuned model object.

from pycaret.datasets import get_data boston = get_data(‘boston’) experiment_name = setup(data = boston, normalize = True)

tuned_knn = tune_model(model = ‘knn’, supervised_target = ‘medv’)

This will return tuned k-Nearest Neighbors model.

Parameters

  • model (string, default = None) –

  • ID of the models available in model library (Enter) –

  • Model (ID) –

  • --------- (-------) –

  • Angle-base Outlier Detection ('abod') –

  • Clustering-Based Local Outlier ('cluster') –

  • Connectivity-Based Outlier Factor ('cof') –

  • Histogram-based Outlier Detection ('histogram') –

  • k-Nearest Neighbors Detector ('knn') –

  • Local Outlier Factor ('lof') –

  • One-class SVM detector ('svm') –

  • Principal Component Analysis ('pca') –

  • Minimum Covariance Determinant ('mcd') –

  • Subspace Outlier Detection ('sod') –

  • Stochastic Outlier Selection ('sos') –

  • supervised_target (string) –

  • of the target column for supervised learning. (Name) –

  • method (string, default = 'drop') –

  • method set to drop (When) –

  • will drop the outlier rows from training dataset (it) –

  • supervised estimator (of) –

  • method set to 'surrogate' (when) –

  • will use the (it) –

  • function and label as a feature without dropping the outliers from (decision) –

  • dataset. (training) –

  • estimator (string, default = None) –

  • Name Task (ID) –

  • ---------- ---------- (--------) –

  • Logistic Regression Classification ('lr') –

  • K Nearest Neighbour Classification ('knn') –

  • Naive Bayes Classification ('nb') –

  • Decision Tree Classifier Classification ('dt') –

  • SVM - Linear Kernel Classification ('svm') –

  • SVM - Radial Kernel Classification ('rbfsvm') –

  • Gaussian Process Classifier Classification ('gpc') –

  • Multi Level Perceptron Classification ('mlp') –

  • Ridge Classifier Classification ('ridge') –

  • Random Forest Classifier Classification ('rf') –

  • Quadratic Discriminant Analysis Classification ('qda') –

  • Ada Boost Classifier Classification ('ada') –

  • Gradient Boosting Classifier Classification ('gbc') –

  • Linear Discriminant Analysis Classification ('lda') –

  • Extra Trees Classifier Classification ('et') –

  • Extreme Gradient Boosting Classification ('xgboost') –

  • Light Gradient Boosting Classification ('lightgbm') –

  • CatBoost Classifier Classification ('catboost') –

  • Linear Regression Regression ('lr') –

  • Lasso Regression Regression ('lasso') –

  • Ridge Regression Regression ('ridge') –

  • Elastic Net Regression ('en') –

  • Least Angle Regression Regression ('lar') –

  • Lasso Least Angle Regression Regression ('llar') –

  • Orthogonal Matching Pursuit Regression ('omp') –

  • Bayesian Ridge Regression ('br') –

  • Automatic Relevance Determ. Regression ('ard') –

  • Passive Aggressive Regressor Regression ('par') –

  • Random Sample Consensus Regression ('ransac') –

  • TheilSen Regressor Regression ('tr') –

  • Huber Regressor Regression ('huber') –

  • Kernel Ridge Regression ('kr') –

  • Support Vector Machine Regression ('svm') –

  • K Neighbors Regressor Regression ('knn') –

  • Decision Tree Regression ('dt') –

  • Random Forest Regression ('rf') –

  • Extra Trees Regressor Regression ('et') –

  • AdaBoost Regressor Regression ('ada') –

  • Gradient Boosting Regression ('gbr') –

  • Multi Level Perceptron Regression ('mlp') –

  • Extreme Gradient Boosting Regression ('xgboost') –

  • Light Gradient Boosting Regression ('lightgbm') –

  • CatBoost Regressor Regression ('catboost') –

  • set to None (If) –

  • model is used by default for both classification (Linear) –

  • regression tasks. (and) –

  • optimize (string, default = None) –

  • custom_grid (list, default = None) –

  • default (By) –

  • pre-defined list of fraction values is iterated over to (a) –

  • the supervised objective. To overwrite default iteration (optimize) –

:param : :param pass a list of fraction value to iterate over in custom_grid param.: :param For Classification tasks: :param Accuracy: :param AUC: :param Recall: :param Precision: :param F1: :param Kappa: :param For Regression tasks: :param MAE: :param MSE: :param RMSE: :param R2: :param RMSLE: :param MAPE: :param If set to None: :param default is ‘Accuracy’ for classification and ‘R2’ for: :param regression tasks.: :param fold: :type fold: integer, default = 10 :param Number of folds to be used in Kfold CV. Must be at least 2.: :param verbose: :type verbose: Boolean, default = True :param Status update is not printed when verbose is set to False.: :param Returns: :param ——–: :param visual plot: :type visual plot: Visual plot with fraction param on x-axis with metric to :param ———– optimize on y-axis. Also: :param prints the best model metric.: :param model: :type model: trained model object with best fraction param. :param ———–:
